channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkey in Turmoil and Chaos Since Purge Aimed at Dissenters
item.media:description: A sign in Istanbul asks for yes votes on Sunday in a referendum that would expand the powers of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, who is pictured on the sign.
item.description: The government has fired or suspended about 130,000 people suspected of being dissidents from the public and private sectors since a coup attempt last summer.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Bama County Journal: China’s Aged and Sick Flock to a Hamlet Known for Longevity
item.media:description: Baimo Cave in Bama County, China, an attraction that is said to harbor healing powers. Visitors flock to the county, which has been called China’s longevity capital, to cure their ailments.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Visitors hoping to cure their ailments or simply have a longer life head to Bama County, in southern China, which is known as the country’s “longevity capital.”
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: The Interpreter: Why the Syrian Chemical Weapons Problem Is So Hard to Solve
item.media:description: A victim of the chemical weapons attack in the Syrian province of Idlib last week being taken to a hospital in Turkey.
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad’s willingness to use chemical weapons is driven by his own grim strategy, but also by the fundamental nature of the Syrian conflict.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: BRITAIN’S UNEASY LABOR FORCE: Britain’s Uneasy Labor Market
item.media:description: The scene near the Houses of Parliament in central London after the referendum vote in June.
item.description: Britain’s economy is thriving, and unemployment is at its lowest level since 1975. But new data exposes potential trouble spots.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Iraqi Held in Borussia Dortmund Attack Is Suspected of ISIS Ties
item.media:description: The Borussia Dortmund team bus after it was bombed on Tuesday on the way to a match in Dortmund, Germany.
item.description: A spokeswoman for the federal prosecutor in Germany said there wasn’t enough evidence to link him to the soccer team bus bombing, but he should remain detained.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Assad Says Videos of Dead Children in Syria Chemical Attack Were Faked
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria in an interview from Damascus on Wednesday.
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad doubled down on denials of responsibility for the attack, contending the episode had been staged as a pretext for a U.S. strike.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.N. Experts Condemn Killing and Torture of Gay Men in Chechnya
item.media:description: Ramzan A. Kadyrov, the leader of Chechnya. A spokesman for him has denied reports of the violent persecution of gay and bisexual men by saying, “You cannot arrest or repress people who just don’t exist in the republic.”
item.description: Reports have emerged of large-scale abductions and abuse of men perceived to be gay or bisexual carried out by security forces.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trudeau Unveils Bill Legalizing Recreational Marijuana in Canada
item.media:description: Crowds celebrate National Marijuana Day last year on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Canada.
item.description: The bill, which is expected to pass, would make Canada the second nation to completely legalize marijuana as a consumer product.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: A Win Over Sexism in Brazil: A Soap Star Is Punished for Harassment
item.media:description: A crowd gathered in Rio de Janeiro to watch the soap opera “Avenida Brasil” in 2012. This week, the star of another popular soap opera, “The Law of Love,” apologized for sexually harassing a female colleague on set.
item.description: The Globo network’s suspension of José Mayer was applauded by an increasingly active movement that has long denounced deep-seated sexism in Brazil.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS

item.title: News Analysis: Trump’s Previous View of NATO Is Now Obsolete
item.media:description: President Trump with Jens Stoltenberg, the secretary general of NATO, at a news conference on Wednesday at the White House.
item.description: As a candidate, Donald J. Trump disparaged the alliance. But as president, and facing a fresh conflict with Russia, he now embraces the organization as a pillar of security.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Feature: Inside Turkey’s Purge
item.media:description: A poster of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in Istanbul.
item.media:credit: VII for The New York Times
item.description: As the ruling party expands the ranks of its enemies, life in a fragile democracy becomes stranger and stranger.
item.dc:creator: SUZY HANSEN
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: 18 Syrian Fighters Allied With U.S. Are Killed in Coalition Airstrike
item.media:description: Members of the American-backed Syrian Democratic Forces in Tabqah, Syria, in March.
item.description: The deaths were the third instance in a month of American-led airstrikes possibly killing civilians or allies in the fight against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: China Says Its Trade With North Korea Has Increased
item.media:description: The Friendship Bridge between China and North Korea. Data released on Thursday showed that China’s trade with the North grew 37.4 percent in the first quarter of this year from the period in 2016.
item.description: Trade was up over all in the first quarter, even though Beijing said it had complied with United Nations sanctions and stopped buying coal.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and YUFAN HUANG

item.title: IHT Retrospective Blog: 1967: U.K. to Defy Spain on Gibraltar Flights
item.description: Britain announced that it will defy any attempts by Spain to close a wide area around Gibraltar to air traffic.
item.dc:creator: INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: Dispatch from Kandahar: Without a Motorcycle in Kandahar, ‘You Are Like a Prisoner’
item.description: The ubiquity of motorcycles shapes daily life in this Afghan city, where they outnumber cars by more than two to one.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Europe Edition: Russia, Hungary, Dortmund: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER

item.title: Uganda Tries to Commit Critic of President to Mental Institution
item.media:description: President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda at an election rally in Kampala, the capital, in 2016. He is in power 31 years after setting out as a great hope for African democracy and routinely intimidates dissidents and journalists.
item.description: The country’s top prosecutor sought this week to use a colonial-era law to commit a prominent critic of President Yoweri Museveni after a series of Facebook posts.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: A Birthday Chorus for Zuma: Resign Now
item.description: On President Jacob Zuma’s birthday, tens of thousands of people protested outside his office in Pretoria, South Africa, calling on him to quit.

item.title: Court Approved Wiretap on Trump Campaign Aide Over Russia Ties
item.media:description: Carter Page, a former Trump campaign adviser, during an appearance in Moscow in December.
item.description: To get permission to wiretap Carter Page, an adviser to the Trump campaign, last summer, the Justice Department had to show probable cause that he was acting as a Russian agent.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MATT APUZZO
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods

item.title: At Meeting, Putin and Tillerson Find Very Little to Agree On
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Sergey V. Lavrov, right, and Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson at a news conference on Wednesday in Moscow.
item.description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson said after meeting President Vladimir V. Putin that Russia and the United States needed to “put an end to this steady degradation.”
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Hungary Law That Could Close Soros-Backed University Faces Uncertainty
item.media:description: Protesters rallied in Budapest on Wednesday against a bill that would effectively shut down Central European University, an institution founded by George Soros.
item.description: Even as an E.U. official said that Central European University should operate “undisturbed,” Hungary’s government appeared to be having second thoughts.
item.dc:creator: HELENE BIENVENU and BALINT BARDI

item.title: Russia Vetoes U.N. Resolution Condemning Syria Chemical Attack
item.media:description: The United Nations Security Council voting on a draft resolution on Syria on Wednesday. The resolution won 10 votes, but Russia vetoed it, the eighth time the country has used its veto power to back the Syrian government.
item.description: The resolution would have strengthened the ability of investigators to look into the attack that killed dozens of civilians. The United States blames Syria’s president.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: United Airlines, Syria, Betsy DeVos: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.media:credit: U.S. State Department, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Riddle of Why Hitler Didn’t Use Sarin Gas Remains Unsolved
item.media:description: Victims of a chemical attack in Khan Sheikhoun, in Idlib Province, Syria, on April 4. The gas was later identified as the lethal nerve agent sarin.
item.description: Theories abound as to why the deadly nerve agent was not used during World War II, which could have dealt a major blow to the Allies, who didn’t know about the lethal arms.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: E.U. Seeks Stronger Protections for Child Migrants
item.media:description: Migrants in November 2015 at the Moria processing center on Lesbos, a Greek island.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Recommendations by the bloc’s executive body call for a person responsible for child protection in all migrant reception centers and at all stages of the asylum process.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Asia and Australia Edition: Syria, Ahmadinejad, United Airlines: Your Morning Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES McDERMID

item.title: Lula and Simba, Last Surviving Animals at Mosul Zoo, Have Been Rescued
item.media:description: Lula, a bear from the zoo in Mosul, after arriving at an animal rehabilitation shelter in Jordan.
item.description: Lula, a bear, and Simba, a lion, were taken to a wildlife shelter in Jordan after being saved from their home, which was severely damaged in battles for control of the city.
item.dc:creator: RANA F. SWEIS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: European Court Strikes Down Required Sterilization for Transgender People
item.media:description: A gay pride parade in Paris in 2013. Gay and transgender activists in Europe have argued that a sterilization requirement of transgender people was an institutionalized violation of human rights.
item.description: Activists celebrated the ruling, though it does not mean immediate legal change in the countries that require sterilization.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Tillerson: ‘Low Level of Trust’ Between U.S. and Russia
item.description: Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson met with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for two hours and discussed a range of issues on Wednesday.

item.title: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, Ex-President of Iran, Files to Run Again
item.media:description: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the former Iranian president, was surrounded by members of the news media after registering to run on Wednesday.
item.description: The surprising decision by Mr. Ahmadinejad, who became notorious in the West by threatening Israel and denying the existence of the Holocaust, may test Iran’s establishment.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
